intro: Dorema chironium, commonly known as the Kashmir Himalayan poppy, is a flowering plant native to the high altitudes of the Himalayas. It belongs to the Papaveraceae family and is characterized by its striking, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in rocky and alpine environments, thriving at elevations between 2,500 and 4,500 meters. Its leaves are alternate, palmately lobed, and often covered in a dense layer of fine hairs. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind, contributing to its survival in harsh mountainous conditions.
